{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with a lesion on the cheek with raised, pearly borders and with telangiectasias on the surface of the lesion. These are classic signs of Basal cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma usually presents as a firm red nodule, or a flat lesion with a scaly, crusted surface, which is not the case here. Warts are small, fleshy bumps caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), and they don't usually have pearly borders or telangiectasias. Actinic keratosis presents as rough, scaly patches on the skin, which also doesn't match the description.", "answer_choice": "A"}
